prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our choice of band 7 is dictated by the combined requirement for high angular resolution and high mass sensitivity in tracers that are largely optically thin (continuum for the dust, 13CO and C18O for the gas).
The spectral setup includes two high frequency resolution windows on the 13CO and C18O 3-2 lines in the first baseband. The velocity resolution of 0.11 km/s is far below Keplerian velocities and close to the expected low levels of turbulence in the disks. The remaining three basebands are primarily used to provide broad bandwidth for measuring the continuum. The USB contains two lines of interest, however, so we observe at moderate velocity resolution. The CN 3-2 line is expected to be detectable in these short integrations (Oberg et al. 2011, ApJ, 734, 98), provides a useful diagnostic of disk sizes and potentially disk winds, and will be observed at 0.5 km/s resolution. The CS 7-6 line lies in the higher frequency USB baseband and we will observe it at 1 km/s resolution. This is a diagnostic of warm, dense gas and was detected in Cycle 0 observations of Orion disks (Mann et al. submitted to ApJ).
The array configuration is chosen to provide high angular resolution while maintaining full sensitivity to the expected largest scales. At the distance to the sources of 150-200pc, the linear resolution is 17-23 AU in radius and the largest scale is 320-430 AU. These are well matched to protoplanetary disk sizes.
The integration time is near the minimum below which overheads dominate. Decreasing it would reduce the sensitivity substantially for marginal reduction in total time. The continuum rms of 0.30 mJy/beam corresponds to a 3-sigma dust mass sensitivity of 0.4 Earth masses and we should detect Saturnian (0.3 Jupiter) masses of gas at 3-sigma sensitivity in both lines at the corresponding rms of 20 mJy km/s/beam. These will be meaningful physical constraints on all members of our sample.
The data volume from this survey of 98 sources will be very large. We have a large team to handle this and have expertise in both simple and sophisticated state-of-the-art physical-chemical disk models. Immediately after reducing the data, we can phenomenologically characterize the dust and gas images, looking for patterns and outliers. Our quantitative analysis will proceed in steps of increasing complexity: we will derive first order measures of the dust with a "standard" Beckwith grain opacity and gas masses from the parametric modeling of the 13CO and C18O integrated line intensities. Ultimately, we will use the full DALI code to model the dust and gas simultaneously and measure surface density profiles.

Our choice of band 7 is dictated by the combined requirement for high angular resolution and high mass sensitivity in tracers that are largely optically thin (continuum for the dust, 13CO and C18O for the gas).
The spectral setup includes two high frequency resolution windows on the 13CO and C18O 3-2 lines in the first baseband. The velocity resolution of 0.11 km/s is far below Keplerian velocities and close to the expected low levels of turbulence in the disks. The remaining three basebands are primarily used to provide broad bandwidth for measuring the continuum. The USB contains two lines of interest, however, so we observe at moderate velocity resolution. The CN 3-2 line is expected to be detectable in these short integrations (Oberg et al. 2011, ApJ, 734, 98), provides a useful diagnostic of disk sizes and potentially disk winds, and will be observed at 0.5 km/s resolution. The CS 7-6 line lies in the higher frequency USB baseband and we will observe it at 1 km/s resolution. This is a diagnostic of warm, dense gas and was detected in Cycle 0 observations of Orion disks (Mann et al. submitted to ApJ).
The array configuration is chosen to provide high angular resolution while maintaining full sensitivity to the expected largest scales. At the distance to the sources of 150-200pc, the linear resolution is 17-23 AU in radius and the largest scale is 320-430 AU. These are well matched to protoplanetary disk sizes.
The integration time for this subset of the sample consisting of the M dwarfs is twice that of the higher mass stars as we expect the disk emission to be weaker. The corresponding rms values are 40% lower which translates into greater mass sensitivity and improves our ability to measure the properties of the disks across as wide a range of stellar masses as possible.
The data volume from this survey of 98 sources will be very large. We have a large team to handle this and have expertise in both simple and sophisticated state-of-the-art physical-chemical disk models. Immediately after reducing the data, we can phenomenologically characterize the dust and gas images, looking for patterns and outliers. Our quantitative analysis will proceed in steps of increasing complexity: we will derive first order measures of the dust with a "standard" Beckwith grain opacity and gas masses from the parametric modeling of the 13CO and C18O integrated line intensities. Ultimately, we will use the full DALI code to model the dust and gas simultaneously and measure surface density profiles.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to survey the gas and dust in 98 protoplanetary disks in the nearby Lupus star forming region. This is a complete sample of all known optically visible stars with large infrared excesses and stellar masses > 0.1 solar. We will observe the 13CO and C18O 3-2 lines and have developed models to derive total gas masses and surface density profiles. The sensitivity of these data is a few Martian masses (0.2-0.4 Earth) in the dust and Saturnian masses (0.1-0.3 Jupiter) in the gas. We will be able to detect the lowest mass disks in both the continuum and line for a gas-to-dust ratio similar to the ISM. We will observe to about 20 AU linear resolution, sufficient to measure sizes and surface density profiles in all but the smallest disks. At these scales we also expect to see features such as inner holes and azimuthal asymmetries that may signpost planet formation. The sample size, sensitivity, and resolution of this survey will provide much needed demographics for disk studies and planetary synthesis models. To maximize its impact, we will reduce the proprietary period to 3 months and make the data products available through a dedicated disk archive within 1 year.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
